source.citation: Nakagawa, M. et al. 2010. Effect of tree size on time of each work element and processing productivity using an excavator-based single-grip harvester or processor at a landing. Journal of Forest Research 15(4):287-295.
source.document: notes/reference/Effect of tree size on time of each work element and processing productivity using an excavator-based single-grip harvester or processor at a landing.pdf
notes: Study site: 43-year-old Sachalin fir thinning near Takinoue, Hokkaido; 41 stems processed with a 12 t Timberjack 746B + Komatsu PC138US carrier.
Mean DBH 19.6 cm (range 10–28 cm), mean height 13.7 m; mean piece volume 0.25 m³ (range 0.056–0.529 m³).
Delay-free productivity model: 0.363 * DBH^1.116 m³/PMH (DBH in cm). Alternative model: 20.46 * volume^0.482 m³/PMH (volume in m³).
Observed average productivity = 10.78 m³/PMH (0.093 PMH/m³). Feeding/measuring + swing consumed ~68% of cycle time.
